intro: Noccaea fendleri subsp. idahoense, commonly known as Idaho mountain spinach, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, cruciform flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils in alpine and subalpine environments. It has basal leaves that are pinnately divided, and its stems are often hairy. The species is valued for its nutritional content and is sometimes used in local foraging practices.
